summary: acute exacerbations adversely affect chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) prognosis by accelerating loss of lung function. it is important to know microorganisms that commonly cause exacerbations in the patient groups classified according to clinical and functional characteristics. studies have shown that patients with severe or very severe air flow limitation tend to be at high risk of exacerbations. higher exacerbation rates are associated with a faster loss of forced expiratory volume in 1 second (FEV1) and greater worsening of overall health status. a significant relationship between low FEV1 and frequency of various organisms, including Pseudomonas aeruginosa and Enterobacteriaceae, was shown. however, there have not been similar studies that have included symptom scores and exacerbation frequency in the groups classified according to the new GOLD staging system. CAT and a pulmonary function test were provided to the patients. all pulmonary function tests were performed by the same technician after the administration of 400 g salbutamol while the patient was stable. the combined COPD assessment scaling was applied according to GOLD 2011 criteria. mycoplasma pneumoniae, Legionella pneumophila, Staphylococcus aureus, Klebsiella pneumoniae, Escherichia coli, and Enterobacter cloacae bacteria were done with an RDB 2245/RDB 2246 BAC HOSPITAL (Gen ID®; Autoimmun Diagnostika GmbH) multiplex PCR kit according to the experts’ suggestions. patients were divided into four groups, GOLD A, B, C, and D. Sputum samples were taken from patients to a sterile container after rinsing the mouth and throat. all patients were informed about the study. their written consent was taken. 114 patients, whose ages
